Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: Identity-attack and Non-identity-attack. Anything harsh or derogatory regarding someone's identity, such as their looks, race, gender, or sexual orientation, is considered an identity attack.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Silly Americans, laws are for poor people.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on Americans.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: More annoying drivel from plagiarist Wente.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: The Canadian gang of fools at the table.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be identity-attack because the comment contains identity attacks on Canadian.

Comment: You do know what a control group is for right?   It is what you compare against what you're studying.  

Now you ask what do you need to know about head start?  Head Start is a program of the U.S..Dept of Health and Human Services that provides comprehensive early childhood education, health, nutrition, and parent involvement services to low-income children and their families.  Eligibility is largely income-based, although each local program includes other eligibility criteria, such as disabilities and services needed by other family members. Families must earn less than 100% of the federal poverty level.

In overall,  the study says it doesn't matter if you went to preschool or not.  Most of the children by the 3rd grade showed no significant positive impacts on math skills, prewriting, promotion, or teachers' reports of children's school accomplishments.  

Bottom line,  If you want your children to do good in school,  parent involvement is important.

Comment: Glad you all could make it up. I have a tale to tell.  I was working as s surveyor and geologist in what  I believe to be the first party over the Atagan pass  on foot.  We were let off from the helicopter at the base of the ugly grade (before there was a grade or road) and worked our way up for the rest of the day.  At the end of the day, the helicopter came to find us but was working 2,000 feet below us.  ( with the wisdom of the time, our radios could not talk to the helicopter, or camp, go figure)  A thin shaft of sunlight came through and I was able to catch the helicopter with my signal mirror and we went home warm and safe.  Point: The mirrors never lose their charge and never go off channel.  If the sun is there, they are there.  they have helped me out no less than seven times, some far more important than the above. Good luck, enjoy, try it again in the spring when the flyway is open.

Comment: I am a Diclectin baby and a Diclectin mother--my mother took it throughout her pregnancy with me, and I took it throughout my first pregnancy, and for about half of my second pregnancy. My pregnancies defied the "morning" sickness label, and also defied assumptions that nausea and vomiting in pregnancy is an affliction of the first trimester only: I was sick all day every day for nine months for my first pregnancy, blessedly less in the second. I found that Diclectin reduced the nausea and vomiting but did not eliminate them. Once on Diclectin, I was vomiting only once or twice a day and the nausea was somewhat more intermittent than it had been. Not an easy spit-up, mind you, but full gut-wrenching vomiting. But that was a massive improvement over all day, and it helped me keep down enough calories to curb the weight loss and start putting on weight. I wouldn't say it was a wonder drug--I still felt far from normal--but it made it more bearable.

Comment: Section 21. Cemetery Companies - IRC 501(c)(13) Operational Requirements where no one can pay, the only valid non profit in the world.
Nonprofit mutual cemetery companies must operate exclusively for the benefit of members. Charitable activities, such as providing burial for indigents, and other non=profits, are considered to be within the scope of such activities.

Other nonprofit cemetery companies and crematoria must be operated solely for the purpose of the disposal of bodies by burial or cremation of any other non-profit agency. They are not permitted to engage in any business not necessarily incident to that purpose. No part of the net earnings may inure to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual, or any other non-profit agency on their way to the crematorium.

The Southern economy was premised on slavery and the leaders perceived, probably correctly, that the end of slavery would cause a tremendous upheavel in Southern life...both culturally and economically.  Those leaders also perceived (again, likely very correctly) that, with the election fo Abraham Lincoln and the ever-growing power of the Abolitionist movement, slavery in the U.S. was coming to an end....and likely in the near future.  Rather than seek to negotiate as favorable a transition as possible, likely including compensation for emancipated slaves, the South chose to secede.  It's no surprise that most the young men in the South chose to support secession. They were raised in the South and slavery was part of the values system of their lives.  ....and, yes, those damn Yankees were going to end slavery.  Gary Crum

Comment: I agree that it has to be more than a simple majority of votes cast, but I think the voting threshold should be even higher than you suggest (maybe 60% by population)?  It is so fundamental a change,  so expensive and something that is almost impossible to undo.  The experience of independence could be great, but could turn out to be awful. There is no guarantee that Catalan will be let into the EU, if they want that, or be allowed access to the Schengen  zone.  They may have to negotiate trade treaties with the rest of the world from a position of weakness.  These things could all give a serious case of regret to the populace.  Given that downside risk, I think you need a solid super-majority to show that people truly want it before it can happen, because there just seems to be practically no going back.  The spurned rump of Spain is going to be in no mood, for likely decades, if ever, to let a remorseful separatist Catalan back in if things don't work out for them.

Comment: Your point is well taken, the headline of my letter was an unreasonable conclusion. The total injury figures alluded to were raw numbers, and without participation data, any conclusion about rates would be unfounded. But the RG writes the headlines, not the author, so your beef is with them.

It is also not a reasonable conclusion to state "recent news shows that almost all college and pro football players get serious head injuries".  That news was based on studies involving individuals whose families donated the samples, probably because the individuals displayed symptoms.  They were not samples from a general population of football players. Even the researchers themselves said it was impossible to draw any significant conclusions.
So let's agree more research is warranted, and in the meantime, let's continue to improve head injury awareness and prevention in all sports and activities.
Rob Harvey

Comment: We have not needed new laws since God wrote the first 10.  What we have needed is proper enforcement, especially from the Judicial end of things.
>
Under food for thought:  I once worked for a Sheriff's Dept. in the lower 48 which included a few years working in the County jail.  We found an interesting phenomenon occurring amongst inmates about to be sentenced.  If they were to be sentenced to 9 months or more in the county jail, or 1 or more years in prison, almost all were opting for the longer prison terms over the county jail term.  They thought the prison term had many more freedoms and benefits available to it and chose that option over the shorter but more restrictive county jail sentence.  Clearly, we are doing something wrong with our prisons when inmates would rather serve time there rather than in the county jail.  What I believe we need to do is go back to making prisons real places of punishment.  How did 'benefits' EVER come into play with prison life - UNREAL!

Comment: I really don't have a stance on citizenship vs. legal residency. I think one could make a good argument either way. The larger point is that we need some sort of reasonable path to documented legal status.

No, I'm not normally in favor of LLE picking and choosing which federal laws to enforce. But there is a role for reason here and a hierarchy of need. Child pornography, federal hate crimes, etc. are a bit ratcheted up in urgency when compared to busting the guy from Juárez painting my neighbor's house. It's one thing to stumble upon an undocumented alien while in the normal course of police work. It's another to dedicate already stretched man hours and limited human resources to hunting down nonviolent offenders.

But I'm with you on putting the onus on ICE to expeditiously collect detainees. My hunch is that if the feds were really held to that, this whole ill-conceived business would be rethought pretty quickly.

Comment: It's an odd argument to compare a tax loop-hole to  employment terms and conditions. I agree that DB pension plans are risk-skewed, but this is not a powerful argument. The rule change is about tax fairness, and it's problematic to try and work public service DB pension plans into the tune. 

Note that, historically, if you as an individual saved 20% of your before tax income and invested it in a broad TSX index etf re-investing all income, you would end up at 65 with an amount of capital that would generate an income much greater than that of 66.66% of the mean of your final 5 years salary, assuming a normal income profile over time and historical rates of return. In other words, if you are pissed at the public service DB pension, it's really that you are pissed that the employer (ie, us) contribution is so high. Which is a perfectly valid position, but it is not an argument against DB pension, but an argument against bad negotiation.

Comment: In attempting to find a percentage of pre-existing conditions that may be genetic I found this most interesting article about GINA, a bill passed out of Congress that was intended to take the fear of discovery by insurance companies out of being genetically mapped for the sake of seeing if a person was predisposed to any diseases. Comment: "Take contraception and abortion for example".

It seems that 2/2 does not follow from 1/2. If, for example, contraception and/or abortion is clearly immoral AND contrary to the common good, the church has an obligation (to society and not only internally) to pursue it as also illegal, not as dominating, imposing it on, society but as a contribution to it. The same would, in this sense, hold for something essential to the common good.

The problem as I see it is (at least) threefold:

1. how the issue is understood, validated, articulated, and pursued.

2. how the processes and conclusions within the civic/political processes, decisions and administration are respected,

3. how matters of membership, individual discernment and conscience are respected.

It seems to me that our Church fails on all three counts. Plus, Church maintains its right despite its obvious failing, while reasonable persons see these failures as denying the right and obligation. And that is the real problem.

Comment: Larry, your historical research is lacking on this. Study the Republican administrations of the 1920s, for example -- as well as earlier -- and you'll find no (or very little) support for your assertions that Republicans believed that government needs to be large enough to ensure every citizen has a decent standard of living. They had other reasons for favoring a strong central government, but they had very little (if any) concern for the livelihoods of ordinary citizens. William Leuchtenberg's new (huge!) volume titled The American Presidency: From Teddy Roosevelt to Bill Clinton will give you a good overview, if you're interested. You're right that the Democrats changed in the 1930s, but they weren't switching places with Republicans (not at that point, that happened much later).

Comment: Yes, I agree that I'm doing something most people wouldn't. And I do borrow against my home with a HELOC.  I've now done it three times in seven years.  The first time, during the financial crisis in 2009, paid off so handsomely that it funded several years of retirement.  The second time, pretty much nothing happened -- no meaningful gains or losses and I sold the dividend stocks at break-even.
I don't think this is as risky as many others seem to.  The interest rate on my HELOC is currently 3.2%.  I pretty much tune out the market unless I can buy quality dividend paying stocks (big banks, BCE, Telus, Fortis, and some quality investment trusts when I can get a dividend that covers the 3.2% interest, plus inflation (currently 1.5%), plus a safety margin.  In February, 2009 when it looked like the financial world was ending, I bought shares of Bank of Montreal, for example.  Its common shares were paying a 9.6% dividend.  BMO has paid a dividend longer than any other company in Canada.

Comment: I'm not over-eager to defend conservatives -- I don't consider myself one -- but I've never found this line of argument persuasive. Remember:

>>Since 2015, Anchorage law has allowed people to use bathrooms and locker rooms in places open to the public that correspond with their gender identity.

In other words, it was *progressives* who inserted the heavy hand of the law into this. The initiative described in the story is a *response* to that assertion of power.

To illustrate, consider the libertarian position (which incidentally is the one I favor). This position would hold that the government should just stay out of this; and that it's none of anyone's business how any individual business owner decides to manage his or her bathrooms. But wait -- progressives don't WANT that scenario. They WANT the government involved.

One of the signalling molecule jobs of beta hydroxy butyrate is its function as an HDAC1 inhibitor. Perhaps it is that function or one of its other protean functions that seems to reduce craving in addictions.  There are a small group of clinicians using this approach to address your issue.

I expect it is because alcohol is detoxified to acetyl co A the same unit of energy currency that is traded in fat metabolism. Comment: So what you're saying is that the original Canadian government should have slaughtered the Indians, like they did down south in the US. Then there would be no question of ownership. Because, they were not "defeated" is not relevant (and the natives generally were not at war with the British, so who was there to defeat?). 

The constitution is legally relevant - and native people don't own the land, especially where Title has not been proven in Court, like in this case (and Canada still has rights to proceed with projects even on titled land). It is possible that another first nation other than the Gixtan could gain title in this area (since there are overlapping "claims" everywhere in BC). These two supposed chiefs would then have no say in the matter of the LNG terminal. Even though indigenous people have not always been treated fairly in the past does not put them above the rules of the present.

Comment: Leave Obamacare alone to fail under its own deficiencies. Order companies who want  to participate in the market to follow a list of guidelines. These guidelines are:
1) You may cross state lines to sell your product.
2) No pre-existing conditions exemptions.
3) Your offering must be available by 1/1/2018 or you wait until 2019 to sell your policies.
4) You must offer a corresponding health savings account.
5) Employees may decide whether to direct their employer to pay an equal amount into a heath savings account or a health maintenance account.
6) COBRA accounts stay in existence.
7) Employees under the age of 30 may elect to have their employer contribution used to reduce their outstanding school loans.
8) Anyone over the age of 24 who does not have insurance must submit 3 monthly payments prior to and wait 90 days before they are entitled to making claims. This goes for newly employed consumers too.
9) Individuals who die with funds left in an HSA goes to their estate.

Comment: Actually, what happened here wasn't life.  What happened here was (i) breach of contract, when the airline bumped a passenger from an airplane seat he had paid for, (ii) fraud, when the airline sold more tickets for the flight than it had seats available, and (iii) assault, when the Chicago Airport Goon Squad busted the guy's head in the process of dragging him off of the airplane. Comment: Not a "ticky tac violation". The problem is the law cannot be written with descriptions of every single item that should be a violation. Because of this, the laws tend to be more generalized and sometimes include items that we don't understand. As an employer, it is up to the employer to ensure an awareness of the laws and ensure they are not being broken. That is why companies usually hire HR specialists. However, small businesses cannot afford to have someone who is a specialist and the government needs to take this into account when assessing fines. Because it was still a violation, it does require a write-up, but there should be latitude when fines are considered and sometimes, sadly the law specifies the fine.

Comment: Matt,  I'm a little nervous about your demonization of teacher's unions.  It seems that if you had your way we could just do away with this difficult business of democracy.  On the one hand, outside organizations that support vouchers and privatization could continue to make massive contributions to support your Elevate Reform slate.  They could continue to go to town talking about what a great job they have been doing.  On the other hand, organizations that tell the other side of the story, like teachers unions, would be banned from participating.  The public would not have to hear that Reform Elevate created such a hostile work environment for the last 8 years that  teachers and principals  flee to other districts.  They wouldn't know about the decline of our ability to compete with other school districts financially.  Nor would they know that our academics are in decline.    
Of course, in that vision, teachers would effectively be muzzled.  And our decline continue unopposed.

Comment: Trudeau is correct that some remarkably bad ideas manage to gain enough popular support that adherents of them could gain representation in a PR system. On the other hand, there are also some very good ideas that, at least initially, gain the support of only a small fraction of the population. If adherents of those very good ideas could get a voice in Parliament, perhaps progress would be more rapid. For instance, if Canada had had PR since 1970, there would have been a voice in parliament all those years pushing marijuana legalization, and it would have been a done deal a couple of decades ago. 

Fringe ideas are not necessarily bad ideas.

Comment: According to Chart 8, The annual worker earnings of residents in the oil patch is approximately $1.5 billion which accounts for only 2/3 of oil patch earnings. Therefore total Statewide wages are approximately $21.0 billion.

A 1% State income tax would raise $8 million from non-resident oil patchers, $15 million from resident oil patchers, and $210 million from all Alaska wage earners.  So don't cut off your nose to spite your face!
PS this is based on gross wages - so tax revenue after exemptions and deductions are taken would be proportionately less.

Comment: If you could not assume that anyone who disagrees with you does so just because they are ignorant, that would be swell. I understand how Supreme Court rulings work. They establish precedent. But that precedent has to be *applied* first by the Court in order for it to effect a change in law. The groundwork for a lawsuit to establish the ruling you and I would like to see the Court make has already been laid down, sure. But until someone actually brings a case dealing with this issue before the bench, and the court makes a ruling on this issue, specifically, the law hasn’t changed. And even when it is brought forth, I imagine that the Court will not be so broad in its application of the law as to prevent a social media platform from banning anyone at all. It will make exceptions, just as it always does.

Comment: I'd guess you do not realize this or have forgotten it but stocks are not bonds. Bonds hav a maturity date, stocks do not. If you invest $100,000 in a five year (safe) bond, in five years you receive your $100,000 back. That is referred to as the bond maturing at par. Between now and then (over the five-year period) that bond could be worth $80,000 or $110,000, more or less. The price tha the bond trades at will fluctuate up and down with various factors that cause supply and demand to change. However, smeone who bought this bond to hold for the five-year term (and I realize how difficult that may be from a trader's point of view to understand but people actually do this---invest for the full five year term) can and likely will totally ignore these price fluctuations. After all, they are meaningless to someone with this objective of buying for the term of the bond. Regardless of what happens during the term of the bond, the destination remains the same. Paper gains/losses mean zip.

Comment: Our lack of a "self-generating" economy is a direct result of federal overreach. Those of us who were here in 1978 when Carter instituted D-2 remember the companies moving in and the opportunities that were growing from the discovery of oil. That all went away when companies became aware that they would be under constant and intrusive federal scrutiny even when they operated on state or private lands. The jobs dried up, mining companies left the state, only the huge corporations remained.

If Alaska were an independent nation able to offer realistic terms to resource developers, we would have that "self-generating" economy. Think Norway ... or Saudi Arabia.

Instead, we remain a colony of the United States with a placebic salve of statehood ... in name only.

Comment: I am as far left as one can get,  and while I imagine I may not agree with much on this site, I can say I WHOLEHEARTEDLY agree with this article and applaud the levity. I was a poly sci/history major and there is NOTHING more that I love than American History, the good, the ugly, the ups and the downs - it all fascinates and inspires me (especially growing up in DC & now living in Philly. It's all around me every day and I LOVE IT!).

But I always found the confederate statue and monument situation a difficult one. It IS our history and we need to preserve it, but... no country in the world memorializes their enemies. These soldiers were not a part of the United States - they created their own nation, waged war on the US & lost. So why do we honor the soldiers of a foreign nation? As Trump said, I like generals that win - these guys didn't. 

But they should never, ever be destroyed. They belong in a museum where they can remind us of our history neutrally, without glorification.

Comment: My husband, now 68, retired" 6 years ago. He started working at 14, put in 3 years of military service (1 yr.Vietnam) + 37 years at the US Post Office. 
After 6 months, he started driving school bus and found a summer job driving a courtesy van full-time with the tourism industry. He enjoys both jobs, but he isn't doing it for fun, it's out of necessity. 
I am on SS disability, unable to work since 2006. My 401 K "disappeared" during the recession and during that time, I was bedridden for 7 years.
In 2002 we downsized from a larger home to a much smaller one after the kids were gone. We bought a used car, no vacations just the occasional trip South for medical or to attend a family funeral.  
2 yrs. ago, turned our furnance off and rely on a wood stove and a space heater to keep us warm. We don't eat out unless we have been invited to dinner. We rely on our son in-laws to hunt and fish for us. 
Never envisioned a time when we stopped working, our parents never did, so why would we?

Comment: I absolutely agree we as a Church should address the issue of racism in this country, in my native country, and everywhere else. I'm not sure what role removing statues should have in that process, because the racism obviously runs deeper. In some cases, removing statues may do nothing more than create an illusion. In my opinion, if the removal of statues is not accompanied by a systemic effort to uproot racist ideas and attitudes, we won't have accomplished anything. So perhaps the removals should come at the end of a process, as a sort of culmination of a national effort to excise a cancer, and their presence till then should serve as a reminder of what remains to be done.
Will our bishops take the lead in bringing an end to racism? They could....but I too have some dubias.

Comment: Real GDP growth of 0.4% is very good, but hardly amazing. We had a higher (0.5%) monthly rate of growth in June 2015, and CTV’s Don Martin, in full Harper-hate mode, sneered at it as miniscule. But you are right. For what it’s worth, this amounts to a 4.9% growth rate annualized, which is much better growth than Canada could possibly sustain over a year or several years. On the other hand, if one looks at PM Trudeau’s growth record from October 2015 to November 2016, the annualized rate of growth has only been 1.5%. If one looks at real GDP growth per member of the active population it is under 0.6%. As of November 2016, real GDP per capita still hasn’t recovered to its December 2014 level prior to the 2015H1 contraction.

Comment: Here is a genuine inquiry: Should anyone (regardless of age, gender or orientation)be held liable for what they do when they are intoxicated? I know that sounds absurd, but I have recently heard and read victim advocates insisting that anyone who is intoxicated is incapable of providing consent to engage in a sex act. If that is so, then why would a similarly intoxicated person be held liable for initiating a sex act (or any other act, for that matter). It seems to me that if we start attributing intoxication with lack of agency that it would apply to everything. If we selectively apply that standard to only one party of a sex act, it is fundamentally unjust and kind of dumb.

Comment: Those programs are there for support, not to represent the victim through the court process. OVR is set up to represent the constitutional rights of the victims as attorneys. Victims for Justice can not represent victims as attorneys. How would you like it if defense counsel demanded your psych/medical records as a victim to try and claim you are not credible? Or to turn over your entire contents on your cell phone? This all becomes public record if granted, and mind you, it usually is. That is what OVR has been set up for, to ensure that the privacy and rights of the victims are upheld. The prosecution does not advocate for the victims, their only job is to notify if there is a hearing which they now source a third party program to do that. This program will only notify about certain hearings, and sometimes after the hearing has happened. Here is more about the constitutional rights for victims: https://ovr.akleg.gov/rights.php. Without OVR, this will fall by the wayside.

Comment: Indeed in totalitarian societies, reporting the 'truth' can (and has been) life threatening.

In the democratic first world however, there is a more complex relationship between reporters, governments, businesses and their audience.  Years ago, a friend at one of the world's largest public relations firms said that at least 50% of what I read in a paper is a public relations article. 

Public relations isn't just for movie stars and retail - governments and political groups and all sorts use public relations content.  The point is to make you buy into whatever the originator is selling - be it a product, an image, a political viewpoint.

Plus our media is so biased, on both left and right.  The left may claim that the right is spouting 'alternative facts', but what the more progressive media often does to sell their point is to cleverly leave out salient facts.  

All these shenanigans have caused the public to distrust media.  That's the sentiment exploited by the U.S. president.

Comment: There's often confusion over what's a tax cut or a tax increase.  What Reagan (mostly) did was seriously lower tax RATES while broadening the tax base (i.e. what gets taxed as income).  Which is the right way to do it.  The positive impact on the economy was historic.

Tax everyone more evenly, with fewer breaks (ideally NO breaks/deductions/credits would be best), and at lower rates.  That way there's more incentive to earn the NEXT dollar when government isn't taking half of it.

The result was a dramatic growth in tax REVENUES from the lower rates, because of the expanding economy and broader base.  

We shouldn't have to relearn that method of success over and over, but sadly, it seems we do.

Comment: No, you're wrong to question the accuracy of the survey that showed that sex assault rates are stable while other crime rates are dropping.  The fact that the police data showed the rate of reported sex assault to be dropping and other reported crime to also be dropping suggests that there was a decline in reporting of sex assaults, not that the data is wrong.  

It's not that the rate of crime reported to police is more accurate, it's that it measures a different thing.  For that matter, it's also possible that the discrepancy is explained in part by poor or inconsistent records keeping by police on sexual assault, which the police already acknowledge has been a problem.

Comment: The 'Star-Spangled Banner'--the original unexpurgated version--includes death-threats to runaway slaves seeking refuge among the British. Logical to conclude it would have a 'special' meaning to many black Americans, past and present.

Mark Twain, horrified by US atrocities in the Philippines campaign, remarked the US flag should be redesigned--from the 'Stars and Stripes' to the Skull and Crossbones.

Comment: Or maybe not. My daughter recently rented an apartment (condo) in a small building (low condo fees) that the owner had just bought for $400K. After 5 years of paying $2000/month rent escalating at 2% her total outlay would be $124,987. If she had bought it with $50K down, her monthlies - including fees, taxes, utilities etc plus mortgage payments would have totaled $156,827. BUT, included in this amount is $52,291 of principal she would have paid off. So her actual cost of ownership - and this assumes no increase in the property value - would have been $104, 535, $20,300 LESS than renting. And that is in today's market. After 10 years, the numbers would be even more compelling. The challenge for most young people is that while owning is a better deal, it requires more capital (the downpayment) and consumes more cash flow. But it also builds equity.

Comment: Re: " What protections would you propose so that such information in the public domain isn't misused?"

This site limits the word count so I can't elaborate in detail. However the NICS database is really a go/no go process and no useful information has to be displayed to facilitate phishing expeditions for identity theft other than what was already known by the user making the query. It’s certainly no more revealing than the national $ex offender registry or the FAA’s pilot and mechanic license query system where the latter provides more detailed information on presumably law-abiding citizens. Basically a person enters the personal information of the transferee and the system responds with a proceed, hold or deny response.

Comment: There are conservatives in Alberta who point the finger at Ottawa and Quebec for the fiscal problems in Alberta.  There are even Alberta separatists who advocate for taking Alberta out of Canada.

If Alberta did manage to separate from Canada then everyone will finally see the reality that Alberta’s fiscal problems are self-imposed by politicians from Alberta.  By the PC governments in the past and by the NDP government in the present.

Alberta is the only province in Canada with no provincial sales tax.  The Albertans who insist that the provincial sales tax is a bad idea are responsible for the financial problems that Alberta faces.

The Alberta Heritage Fund is just peanuts compared to the sovereign wealth funds in other jurisdictions around the world.  It is even tiny compared to what Alaska has.

Alberta has behaved in an irresponsible manner with the provincial finances.  I think the last fiscally responsible premier that Alberta had was Peter Lougheed.

Comment: Being a resident of rural central Alberta I am responsible for all snow removal on my property. My neighbour and I also clean the snow from the county road allowance for 1.5 miles in front of our properties. (We live on an isolated road that is last in line for snow removal by the county graders.) In October I put the blade on my tractor and in April I remove that blade. Also in October I add extra weight to the box of my F-150 to give the 4WD and the winter tires more oomph when dealing with dicey driving conditions.

So far it has been a gentle winter snow-wise in my part of the world. In fact, I would like to see more snow. I enjoy snowshoeing and X-country skiing around my property and currently there is just not enough snow for optimum snowshoeing or X-country skiing.

Suck it up, Vancouver.

Comment: Responding to posts and confronting ad hominem attacks in no way constitutes censorship.  As an old-fashioned ACLU-type liberal, I feel all voices need to be heard.  That doesn't mean one should simply passively accept racist comments for example.  I will offer my opinions and my views.  More often than not, they may differ from yours.  That is the essence of democracy and civil discourse.  

I gather you're not particularly impressed by my comments.  C'est la vie.  I express my views and react to the views of others...Whether you agree, diagree or simply "don't care" isn't important in itself.  Free expression, in in itself neither "offends or frightens" me.  Free expression is a concept central to democracy.  If the CONTENT of the expression offends me, I will convey that feeling..e.g. I will confront a racist slur or other ad hominem attack.  The issue of censorship is the purview of the RG and the guidelines for this site are posted...all you need to do is follow them.  Gary Crum

Comment: This is a tragic loss and my condolences go out to the family and friends.   That said, we'd have never heard about this, because it would never have happened, if somebody had spent less than a hundred bucks on PFDs; life jackets, not free money.    It is little short of suicidal to be in an open boat in any Alaska waters without some sort of flotation device; if anything puts you in the water, your odds aren't good.   The old-time fishermen didn't even bother to learn to swim; get it over quickly.   Sea food restaurants advertise the "icy waters of Alaska," they're icy, and if your body goes into those waters you almost immediately go into shock.   Most deaths come from the gasp from hitting the water that results in ingesting water.   Your life is worth at least $50, so buy a PFD and wear it!

Comment: A week of two ago Governor Kate Brown announced she wouldn't be leading any particular course of action on the budget when the legislature re-convenes.  She urged that the proponents of Measure 97 and business leaders work out some kind of proposal.  It looks like we continue to have a governor who is a mere office holder and not a leader.

Oregon gets about 87% of its revenue from the state's income tax (per the ODR income tax analysis from 2013) so budget solutions should start there since comprehensive tax reform appears unlikely.
I would recommend the following  revenue enhancements relative to the income tax: (1) eliminate the $95 per person tax credit; (2) eliminate the deduction for federal income taxes paid; (3) end any Earned Income Tax Credits under state law.

The people must vote to repeal the "kicker" and allow the state to retain all revenue received.

This would be a compromise package sure to be disliked and picked apart by both liberals and conservatives.

Comment: I have camped out in McCarthy several times this time of year in mid-August. The bears are all over eating the soapberries. The residents are well armed and gun shots to scare off the bears are heard anytime day or night. I have been close to mom and cubs both black bears and grizzly bears. There are many single bears of both species an one amazing bear to us was a large cinnamon black bear that looked like a big grizzly. Hiking at that time of year requires a gun and a can of bear spray an keep them handy.  The weather in that area is chaotic, you start out with a t-shirt on a sunny day and very rapidly a storm will move in suddenly and you will get drenched with rain, which happened to me once, leading to a long chilly hike back to the camp site. It is also cold there this time of year an can easily have freezing temps at night. There is local cell service and that is sketchy. Comment: Great points, Chris.  In the 1970s, former wife and I went back east to visit her parents.  Opened my 20-something eyes.  Although they immigrated to Canada 60-odd years before, as tiny kids, they barely spoke passable English...and never learned to read or write it.  

My wife's older sister lived thousands of kilometres away so I got a map of Canada and tried to explain to "Mama" where she was in relation to the old folks.  Then I tried to explain where my wife and I lived--2,000 kilometres west of what was left of the old farm.  Not sure she understood anything.  The old man's male friends came calling.  They all sat in the living room talking...In Ukrainian. Fascinating. 

Yet, they "contributed."  Ran a farm.  Raised three kids.

Comment: You have a point, but there has long been, more explicitly spelled out in other states, the concept of "unmarked crosswalks."  For example, in New Jersey, it's codified that:

39:4-36. a. The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, except at crosswalks when the movement of traffic is being regulated by police officers or traffic control signals…"

In Hawaii, there exists a sort of "catch-all" rule that (very) loosely covers such situations:

§291C-72  Pedestrians’ right-of-way in crosswalks.:

(b)  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield.

So with the exception of places where signage clearly prohibits pedestrian crossings (the mauka corner at the intersection of Keeaumoku Street and Kapiolani Boulevard is one) all unmarked intersections come with crosswalks.

Comment: For off-pavement, I swear by Kahtoola Microspikes. They're fairly expensive at first blush, pushing $70 per pair, but they'll pay for themselves after you take your first confident step. They're much more aggressive than standard coil or chain-link style traction aids, and are likely the model you referred to with the comment on the triangular shapes. For 95% of trail hiking, they're the perfect solution. They do well in mud/slush, packed snow and most icing. Not so great on exposed rock or any reasonably smooth surface such as plowed pavement. You'll just slide and wobble on the points.

Full-on crampons are the next progression, but are so aggressive that they're typically not well suited to anything but the most extreme conditions, icing and steep slopes. They take attention to manage, too. Ask anyone who has accidentally stepped on their inner calf or ankle how that feels!

Comment: The "consensus" pre-Bomb was essentially identical to the consensus post-Bomb,  which is essentially the 1926 Schrodinger model - electrons as probability distributions -  we still generally use today (we have much better resolution now but the general model's essentially the same). It was itself a derivative of the earlier Bohr/Rutherford models(electrons as discrete particles "orbiting" the nucleus) Einstein was a supporter of this model and spent decades trying to "unify" the forces holding those subatomic particles together. (The Bomb required deep understanding of the Strong Nuclear force, which is a core part of the unified theory Einstein sought even on his deathbed, and which still eludes us today). 

Einstein completed a full doctoral dissertation (Zurich, 1905).

His objection was with certain conclusions of the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum physics, and he seems to have been wrong; the "consensus" proved to be right on that one, and it's still taught today.

Comment: Sorry, even though I'm born and raised in Hawaii, I've never been a huge fan of lei, either giving or receiving.  When I receive a flower lei, I will wear it for the duration of the event but usually by then end, it is wilting or browning so once in the car, I take it off and end up trashing it.  But, especially if it's like a ginger or some other extravagant flower, I always wonder how much the giver spent....$25?  $35?  $100?  Only for me to wear it a couple of hours then end up in the trash?  I almost would prefer a candy/snack lei where I can at least eat it later.  As someone who had to purchase large quantities for school events, there were times when I purchased, say, 50 lei but only half the guests actually showed up.  We could not give away left overs in case the no-shows did show up but of course, they didn't.  So at the end, we had 25 left over lei at $10 each.  I could have spent $250 much more wisely.  Anyway, I made a money-making comment in the UH graduation article!

Comment: I was born after VII and missed the worst of your experience.  However, my first few years in the Church (as an adult convert) involved this merit based salvation, then after a few years of trying to be the perfect Catholic, constantly feeling guilty and fretting about not being good enough for God, my moment of transformative grace came in surrender to the reality that I am a failure...and God loves me that way.  The freedom of not having to be perfect has energized my spiritual life and love for God in a way that perfection never could have.  I now understand St. Paul when he says "the letter of the law kills, but the spirit gives life."  I think (I am riffing on Richard Rohr here) that strict, rule based, merit based religion is a necessary stage of growth on the way to spiritual adulthood.  Some people mistake an adolescent spiritual rebellion for real freedom, others take the opposite tack and are so afraid of rebellion that they never grow to adulthood.

Comment: You're making the same mistake that I describe above. You don't know what the attacker's motives were, and to qualify as terrorism the motive must be specific and the attack rationally planned. How rational was it for this so-called terrorist to attack the Louvre and/or its shopping area, when scores of soldiers had been guarding it for some time? Obviously he could've picked another, unguarded area in Paris to attack passersby with a machete. If he was a bona fide terrorist, that would've been the rational choice, as was the choice of last year's terrorist attack on a Paris nightclub.

It's not simply a matter of quibbling over semantics. By screaming "terrorism" every time something like this happens, politicians invoke visceral fear in the public. As we've just seen in Canada, that can contribute to tragic outcomes.

Comment: Can you explain how that works?   Companies are always looking to be competitive.   If all companies in the same industry are assigned the same tax, the competitive field remains equal.     You're right, a company can pass that cost on, but if competitors don't, (and price fixing is illegal) the company may decide to cut cost in other ways and try to gain price advantage for higher sales.

You're making a good guess on the consequences though.   Many publicly held companies will protect their shareholder dividends, or the share price, by raising their consumer price.   The other favored protection for shareholder return, is withholding wages and benefits from their employee's.   Most every corporate mission statements start with 'increasing shareholder values' and it's been that way for 30 years at least (I know this as an investor).  

What's more important to you, protecting the profit of corporations, (which helps me by the way), or providing basic health care for the marginal.

Comment: Gigi.  I'm not sure why you keep telling me that corporations are not tribes.  If you had read my post for comprehension instead of assuming (incorrectly) what I was saying, you'd see that I stated myself that corporations are not tribes.  My point was that tribes taking over various governmental functions isn't going to reduce the State budget one penny. The tribes, generally, don't have a lot of money, and the corporations, which do have money,  are not tribes and will not be funding tribal governmental functions.  Any governmental function taken over by the tribes will still be funded by the State or Federal government.  I'm not sure how to state my point any more simply or clearly.  Regarding ANTHC, the consortium does far more than provide hospitals and medical clinics. They administer many other health and environmental related functions, like sewer and water systems.  There is substantial state funding in those programs.

Comment: This light rail project is an incredible bargain, just like almost all such projects. Light rail moves people and is immune to congestion issues. In fact, by removing all those tens of thousands of single-occupant vehicles from the road daily these projects also help move freight by reducing congestion delays (unlike adding travel lanes, which has been proven to increase congestion in just a few years).

Compare this project's ability to actually move people to the several hundred million dollars that ODOT wasted replacing the I-5 bridge over the Willamette several years ago. The net benefit was to allow the handful of trucks with GVW over 40 tons to continue using that route, which provides almost no benefit to anyone other than a handful of trucking firms (who have successfully lobbied to keep Oregon as one of the few states that allow commercial trucks over 40 tons).

Comment: The big ISPs will not be seen in Alaska anytime soon. Imagine the expense of laying thousands of miles of subsea fiber optic cable and associated infrastructure -- why do that to serve such a limited, out of the way (and also fickle, saturated, and potentially shrinking) market? Our entire population would fit in the corner of any big city in the lower 48; they have no interest in spending the kind of money it would take to serve a market like that. If they did, they would already be here.

Alaska is just not going to be on the forefront of this type of service. If you want that kind of service you will need closer to the lower 48 large population centers. We're lucky to have what we have. And if your getting 1 gbps/1 TB -- that's pretty darn good given where you are.
